--- title: R Colors in CSS for R Markdown HTML Documents author: Garrick Aden-Buie date: '2020-09-14' slug: r-colors-css categories: - Color - xaringan - Tips - CSS - R Markdown - R - Web Development - Shiny - htmltools description: Use R's colors in HTML R Markdown documents, slides and Shiny apps with this set of CSS stylesheets. image: social-card.png source_link: https://github.com/gadenbuie/garrickadenbuie-com/blob/main/content/blog/2020/2020-09-12-r-colors-css.Rmarkdown keywords: rstats head_custom: | editor_options: chunk_output_type: console references: ~ --- [r-colors-css]: https://pkg.garrickadenbuie.com/r-colors-css [r-colors]: https://rdrr.io/r/grDevices/colors.html [xaringan]: https://slides.yihui.org/xaringan [blogdown]: https://bookdown.org/yihui/blogdown [Shiny]: https://shiny.rstudio.com [xaringanExtra]: https://pkg.garrickadenbuie.com/xaringanExtra ::: {.lead} A modular collection of CSS stylesheets that lets you use any of [R's named colors][r-colors] in your [xaringan] slides, [blogdown] pages, [Shiny] apps... in short in any R Markdown HTML documents. [ pkg.garrickadenbuie.com/r-colors-css][r-colors-css] ::: ## R's Named Colors ::: {.cell} ::: R ships with a list of colors with wonderful names, like [lightgoldenrod3]{.tu-dotted .bg-lightgoldenrod3-hover .white-hover} and [firebrick2]{.tu-dotted .bg-firebrick2-hover .white-hover}. I don't know all of the names and used to turn to an [online list of colors](http://sape.inf.usi.ch/quick-reference/ggplot2/colour) so often that I put it on a mug. In R, you can reference the color by name in nearly any function that applies to colors. They're particularly easy to use in visualizations, like those made with ggplot2, because there are 657 colors and many have 4 variations on the same color hue, indexed by suffixes `1` to `4`. For example, there are 4 variations of [palevioletred]{.tu-dotted .bg-palevioletred-hover .white-hover} that I'm using in the following plot for each of 4 years of Austin housing sales data. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} g_austin_housing + ## A basic ggplot of home sale prices in Austin ## over 4 years, using the ggplot2::txhousing data scale_color_manual( values = c( "palevioletred1", "palevioletred2", "palevioletred3", "palevioletred4", ) ) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.darkmode-opacity-1} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/demo-plot-with-colors-1.svg){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ## Utility CSS If you're used to working with R's color names, they unfortunately don't align with HTML's [named colors](https://html-color-codes.info/color-names/), which means that you can't write a CSS rule like ::: {.cell} ```{.css .cell-code} h3.plot-title { color: palevioletred1; } ``` ::: because `palevioletred1` isn't a valid HTML color. This causes problems if you [use an R color name in a function that write CSS files](https://stackoverflow.com/a/63819561). I've also been interested lately in utility CSS frameworks, like [Tailwinds CSS](https://tailwindcss.com/) and [Tachyons](http://tachyons.io/). What's awesome about these frameworks is that they use small, single-purpose CSS classes â€” called **utility classes** â€” that can be flexibly applied to your HTML elements. I do most, if not all, of my writing in some variant of markdown, and utility classes let me build small components or slightly adjust appearances without having to write a whole lot of CSS. Tailwinds looks amazing, but it requires a moderately complicated build setup, so I've settled on [using Tachyons](https://pkg.garrickadenbuie.com/xaringanExtra/#/tachyons). In particular, it integrates nicely with [xaringan] and other R Markdown outputs where a complete CSS framework is in use (like [R Markdown](https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com) with [bootstrap](https://getbootstrap.com)). For that reason, I've included it in [xaringanExtra], and you can add Tachyons to any R Markdown document with `xaringanExtra::use_tachyons()`. Here's an example of what you can do with utility CSS. If I want to create a simple box with... - a border - on all sides (`.ba`) - that's gray (`.b--gray`) - with a medium line width (`.bw2`), - medium exterior margin (`.ma2`), - large interior padding (`.pa4`), - and a box shadow (`.shadow-1`) ...I can use those classes on the same element. Here are four markdown syntax variations that use those classes. :::: {.panelset .sideways} ::: panel

xaringan

```markdown .b--gray.ba.bw2.ma2.pa4.shadow-1[ Talent is a pursued interest. Anything that you're willing to practice, you can do. â€”Bob Ross ] ``` ::: ::: panel

R Markdown

```markdown ::: {.b--gray .ba .bw2 .ma2 .pa4 .shadow-1} Talent is a pursued interest. Anything that you're willing to practice, you can do. â€”Bob Ross ::: ``` ::: ::: panel

HTML

```html

Talent is a pursued interest. Anything that you're willing to practice, you can do.

â€”Bob Ross

``` ::: ::: panel

htmltools (R)

```r htmltools::div( class = "b--gray ba bw2 ma2 pa4 shadow-1", htmltools::p( "Talent is a pursued interest.", "Anything that you're willing to practice, you can do.", ), htmltools::p("â€”Bob Ross") ) ``` ::: ::: panel

CSS

_Note: this isn't the exact CSS from Tachyons, but it's very similar._ ::: {.cell} ```{.css .cell-code} .b--gray { border-color: #888888; } .ba { border-style: solid; } .bw2 { border-width: .25em; } .ma2 { margin: 1.5em; } .pa4 { padding: 2em; } .shadow-1 { box-shadow: 4px 4px 8px 0 rgba(0,0,0,.2); } ``` ::: ::: :::: ::: {.b--gray .ba .bw2 .ma2 .pa4 .shadow-1} Talent is a pursued interest. Anything that you're willing to practice, you can do. â€”Bob Ross ::: ## R Colors in CSS Wouldn't it be great to have utility CSS classes that you could use in [xaringan] slides and other R Markdown outputs? > [\@grrrck](https://twitter.com/grrrck) First of > all, I ðŸ˜» \`xaringanExtra\`!\ > \ > I am looking at the tachyons colors and can\'t help but think that the > palette is rather limited. \ > \ > Is there a way to intercept a tachyon with a named R color and > generate a proper css with the correct hex code? > > --- Deemah ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¦ ðŸ‡³ðŸ‡´ ðŸ‡¸ðŸ‡ª (@dmi3k) [September 10, > 2020](https://twitter.com/dmi3k/status/1303993734003077120) I thought this was a great idea, so I put together a set of stylesheets with all of R's named colors as CSS classes. You can choose any or all of the three stylesheets, depending on your needs, they each work independently. 1. [r-colors.css](https://pkg.garrickadenbuie.com/r-colors-css/dist/r-colors.css) Classes for setting **foreground** and **background** colors - `.palevioletred1` sets the foreground color - `.bg-palevioletred1` sets the background color 1. [r-colors.hover.css](https://pkg.garrickadenbuie.com/r-colors-css/dist/r-colors.hover.css) Classes for setting foreground and background colors **on hover** - `.palevioletred1-hover` sets the foreground color on hover - `.bg-palevioletred1-hover` sets the background color on hover 1. [r-colors.vars.css](https://pkg.garrickadenbuie.com/r-colors-css/dist/r-colors.vars.css) [CSS variables]() for each color name - `var(--palevioletred1)` for use in other CSS properties For more on how to use the stylesheets, including a searchable table with all of the colors and an interactive color preview, [check out the documentation page][r-colors-css]. As an example, let's update the box example above with some color from R. I used the [color picker table in the documentation][r-colors-css] to pick out an interesting color combination. :::: {.panelset .sideways} ::: panel

CSS

I used the CSS variables stylesheet to add a new CSS rule in addition to the CSS in the example above. This class sets the border color for the box to [paleturquoise4]{.bg-paleturquoise4-hover .white-hover .tu-dotted}. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.css .cell-code} .b--paleturquoise4 { border-color: var(--paleturquoise4); } ``` ::: The other colors used are [steelblue4]{.bg-steelblue4-hover .white-hover .tu-dotted} (text), [mintcream]{.bg-mintcream-hover .tu-dotted} (background), and [mediumvioletred]{.bg-mediumvioletred-hover .white-hover .tu-dotted} (text on hover, from the hover classes stylesheet). ::: ::: panel

xaringan

```markdown .b--gray.ba.bw2.ma2.pa4.shadow-1.steelblue4.bg-mintcream.mediumvioletred-hover.b--paleturquoise4[ Talent is a pursued interest. Anything that you're willing to practice, you can do. â€”Bob Ross ] ``` ::: ::: panel

R Markdown

```markdown ::: {.b--gray .ba .bw2 .ma2 .pa4 .shadow-1 .steelblue4 .bg-mintcream .mediumvioletred-hover .b--paleturquoise4} Talent is a pursued interest. Anything that you're willing to practice, you can do. â€”Bob Ross ::: ``` ::: ::: panel

HTML

```html

Talent is a pursued interest. Anything that you're willing to practice, you can do.

â€”Bob Ross

``` ::: ::: panel

htmltools (R)

```r htmltools::div( class = paste( "b--gray ba bw2 ma2 pa4 shadow-1 steelblue4", "bg-mintcream mediumvioletred-hover b--paleturquoise4" ), htmltools::p( "Talent is a pursued interest.", "Anything that you're willing to practice, you can do.", ), htmltools::p("â€”Bob Ross") ) ``` ::: :::: ::: {.b--gray .ba .bw2 .ma2 .pa4 .shadow-1 .steelblue4 .bg-mintcream .mediumvioletred-hover .b--paleturquoise4} Talent is a pursued interest. Anything that you're willing to practice, you can do. â€”Bob Ross ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ::: :::
